moves.3. Nf3 g5: g5 is an important reponse to the gambit, black isnt going to be half hearted and the gambit is going to be tested.
moves.4. h4:
Bc4 is also sometimes played in this postition and is quite interesting although theory has show white can normally only hope for a draw. 

h4 has the advantage of forcing g4 thereby weakening the kings side
moves.4... g4 5. Ne5: Ng5 should also be considered, black has many ways to counter the gambit.
moves.5... Nf6: As expected defends and attacks e4
moves.8... Qe7 9. Bxf4 Nc6 10. c3: At early stage whites pawn structure looks a little stronger
moves.10... Bf5 11. Nd2 O-O-O 12. O-O-O:
both castle long.

alternativly 12Nxe4, Qxe4,13 Kd2 deserves some attention.
moves.12... Re8: 12... Bg7 is the alternative with the idea of bringing the kings rook to e8 instead
moves.13. Re1:
?! white has to tread carefully and this is one of many mistakes he can make.

g3 or Qe3 would be larger mistakes and cost the game with in 5 moves.
moves.13... Qe6:
! Sharp attack on a2.

14 Kb1 fails...  Nxd2+, 15. Bxd2, Qxe2 16.Bxe2, Rxe2
moves.14... Qa2: White is up a creek with no paddle!!!
moves.15. Qd1 h5: This move shows how helpless white is although Bg7 would have been sharper
moves.16. g3 Bg7 17. Rh2 Nxc3: tidy sac wins the game for black.
moves.18. bxc3 Qxa3+ 19. Kc2: 19.Kb1 is met with Rxe1 20.Qxe1 Qxc3 wins
moves.19... Bxd4 20. Qa1:
last gasp exchange, please.

if 20. cd, Nb4+, 21. Kb1, Rxe1 22. Qxe1, Qa2+, 23. Kc1, Qc2#
moves.20... Nb4+: White resigns as there is no way back.
